body:
It looks like you figured it out https://medium.com/@imesh/apache-openwhisk-runtime-for-ballerinalang-3f18be2d556c?source=linkShare-76041f7388eb-1521463545.

@sciabarracom has offered to write it up.
it's all just a matter of code 😅

@Jiri-Kremser i had a chance to review #2413 again. Indeed the invoke next action in a sequence generates a new span. I think this is close but also wondering if 1. can we bury the span inside a transaction id, and 2. we use somehow ties the start/end markers in so we don't have two mechanism doing the same thing.

It may be best to separate 1 & 2 in terms of the doing the work on the implementation but it makes sense to me to think about both in terms of the design.
Updated the readme based on review feedback. Future PR would not miss on the dots ... :dart:

@mptap 
Thanks a lot for your contribution. I like the idea of limiting the download of some attributes, to prevent dos attacks.

But I also have two concerns: 
- If this nginx is not the front-door, (e.g. Openwhisk is only one of many offerings of one company), than the rate limit would apply on the frontdoor in front of this nginx, right? Then users may experience issues in downloading the CLI, because others do this as well.
- If a company or university wants to introduce OpenWhisk, the students/employees may try to download the CLI at once. In most cases, this is one IP as well. Then the first impression for some of them may be a bad experience.

A agree, that these two examples are only edge-cases. But I think as this is the first experience of a new user, we have to think about it.

One solution to work around this (especially the first problem) may be to make the limits configurable (and add the ability to disable them).

Do you think it makes sense to write a short test, to check that the limits are really applied? (Also to avoid, that they are not applied at some day anymore, because of some configuration changes by other contributors)
Thanks @rabbah for the update and all your help on implementing it!

HI Imesh actually the "pluggable" support is already written. It lives in sciabarracom/incubator-openwhisk-runtime-go and it is in the process of being merged with the new runtime. However I am already working to extend it for Swift but it is actually a general implementation of it for arbitrary binaries. Once done for swift and go it will be a matter of documenting it.

I thought we decided to move the misc defaults to pureconfig (https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/8fb3a6fda1700b8cde1de300492b1461a176df15/common/scala/src/main/resources/application.conf#L131-#L137) and removed them from ansible.  Why do they need to move back to ansible? (we don't use ansible to deploy on kube, which was why moving the defaults out of ansible was desirable)
Agreed re PG.  WIll do it with @csantanapr later today.

Hi @dgrove-oss, I missed that memo, so forgive me if I’m catching up.  Currently there’s logic in the ansible deploy that pre-fetches the images listed in ‘runtime_manifest.json’ and therefore needs to know the defaults as defined in application.conf.  Unfortunately, ansible doesn’t natively support parsing application.conf (one of several reasons I dislike the pure config approach).  For the time being, that means I do have to keep that separate list of overrides in group_vars/all.  Ideally, I’d want to do away with the pre-loading because Controller/Invoker were smart enough to initialize their own runtimes space, but I don’t think we’re there yet.

> Unfortunately, ansible doesn’t natively support parsing application.conf (one of several reasons I dislike the pure config approach)

@jonpspri One possible workaround to address that may be to convert the application.conf to JSON using [typesafe api][2] (see serialization)

```
val config = ConfigFactory.load(); 
val configJSON : String = config.root().render( ConfigRenderOptions.concise() )
```

And then consume that in ansible logic. We can add script to [dev tools][1] which can then be invoked from ansible via gradle command like `gradlew -p tools/dev confToJson`

[1]: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/tree/master/tools/dev
[2]: https://static.javadoc.io/com.typesafe/config/1.3.3/com/typesafe/config/Config.html

>  dont follow the need for the volatile attachments.

The updates to state are performed via stream stage and hence is single threaded. However reads can happen concurrently in other threads so the reference to map is marked as `var` and `volatile`
We will need to designate a single place as the canonical root for the common code. Maybe it can still be this repo.

I'd like to have just one place to get these defaults.  I like @chetanmeh's suggestion of parsing application.conf into ansible so we could make application.conf available to the non-Scala parts of the system. 
@markusthoemmes any thoughts?

Maybe it can be, but should we move it into a different namespace from the runtime-specific code (maybe also out of the tests directory since it will at that point be more of a library)? That would reduce the likelihood of collisions and make it clear when a given runtime has migrated to the new paradigm (whatever that may be).

I was thinking about something along @chetanmeh ‘s way of thinking.  Although I’d rather go the other way... a JSON or YAML config file that is used for configuration of the scala code.  Then we’re less likely to run into synchronization problems and edits/overrides are understood.  I expect that’s a non-starter from an effort standpoint.

Can we leave gradle out of this solution?  Ideally in this scenery, one would use ‘shell:’ to invoke an entry point in the invoker jar to dump the JSON to stdout.  That way we avoid all sorts of build out-of-sync issues.

>  Ideally in this scenery, one would use ‘shell:’ to invoke an entry point in the invoker jar to dump the JSON to stdout.

Makes sense. We can add a utility main class in common (implemented in java to avoid scala dependency in classpath) to dump the config. And in ansible just invoke

```
java -cp typesafe-config.jar:openwhisk-common.jar whisk.utils.ConfigDumper /path/to/output.json
```
@rabbah, @mdeuser, anything else?

@dubee changes look ok... although i think this section probably needs additional rework to better integrate the web action aspects (web action are actions) and clarify the two kinds of `metadata` referenced.
Reopen this pr later, b.c. I need to figure out why the test got failed and avoid disturbing upstream travis build.
Issue looks similar to #3431. Try updating the ansible version 2.4.2.0 (see #3430)

That would be very helpful.

Currently we have to do several get actions request and delete action by action, before we are able to delete the package. That's working, but really not fast.

So such a `force` option would be very helpful.
@cbickel I don’t see you in the co-authored list. Do you need to be? I only see Markus.
Do you use the API or a client (wsk cli)?
Ah. Never mind then. Thanks for trying it out.
I used the REST API, as we have automated processes, and it's part of our software to interact with OpenWhisk
thanks，update the ansible version to 2.4.2.0， the issue has been fixed
@rabbah Do I have to be in the co-authored list? Because my name and image are at the commits anyway, because I'm the author.
It's easier to make this a deployment time parameter for the system vs per action. Did you mean per action?
@dubee @cbickel this will need a pg I think.

This change is ok but I'm wondering if we actually need this still. I a few scripts are still in python (wskdamin, wskdev) but may be python 3 compatible. The reason for python 2.7 was the previous version of the wsk CLI which wasn't python 3 ready.

As a next step there is now an implementation for S3 aka S3AttachementStore (see [here][1] for the diff). Once this PR is merged would create a PR for the S3 support

[1]: https://github.com/chetanmeh/incubator-openwhisk/compare/chetanmeh:attachment-store...chetanmeh:attachment-store-s3

Marking as WIP because apparently, the what’s in the runtime repo and what’s in the core repo was even more messy than I originally anticipated.  Currently moving in the direction of “Make the runtimes self-sufficient for `actionContainer.*` classes”, then I’ll figure out what to factor back into the common libraries.

In my experience, `wskadmin` is not python 3 compatible. For example, `httplib` is particular a python2.7 name, `http.client` in python3. 
This makes me meet some problems under #3474.

However, the `wskadmin` script currently is fined bc I'm not sure `python2.7` binary is available on all platform. 
But in the `WhiskProperties` case, it might be worth to provide the path additionally.

@rabbah - Please bear with me, I'd like to clarify terminology & make sure I'm using it correctly!

I'm currently assuming that what you're saying is that it would be easier to add this feature so it's system-wide & affects all actions equally?

> I'm currently assuming that what you're saying is that it would be easier to add this feature so it's system-wide & affects all actions equally?

correct.

Thanks for clarifying! For my use case, a system-wide deployment parameter would work fine, and I'd be pretty happy with it.

However, I can certainly imagine use cases where users would want per Action capabilities so that they could grant only the required permissions to a given Action rather than needing to maintain a larger set of global permissions that apply to every Action. 

Granting containers only the permissions they really need seems to be a security best practice for containers, and I'm guessing it may have inspired the --cap-drop in the Invoker.

> I'm guessing it may have inspired the --cap-drop in the Invoker.

I'll defer to @jeremiaswerner and @markusthoemmes on the details but in general yes.

Another relevant question: Are you using kubernetes to deploy opnewhisk?
Yes. Currently evaluating it for my use case on a local minikube setup.
Restarted Travis, unrelated Kafka test failed.

Some more warnings:

```
TASK [nginx : copy controller cert for authentication]
 [WARNING]: when statements should not include jinja2 templating delimiters such as {{ }} or {% %}. Found: {{ controller.protocol == 'https' }}
```

```
TASK [cli : Expand the archive into the build directory] 
 [WARNING]: Consider using unarchive module rather than running tar
```

```
TASK [cli : Unarchive the individual zipfiles into binaries] 
 [WARNING]: Consider using unarchive module rather than running unzip
```
@rabbah, can you rebase having trouble with a PG.
done - thanks for the pg.
PG is good on this one. Will wait until @cbickel or @markusthoemmes take a look before merging.

Hmm, seeing an error in the PG while `initdb.yml` is running.
```
TASK [include] *****************************************************************
Wednesday 21 March 2018  16:34:57 -0400 (0:00:00.635)       0:00:00.817 ******* 
fatal: [ansible]: FAILED! => {"reason": "'openwhisk_home' is undefined"}

'openwhisk_home' is undefined
```
@markusthoemmes, @bwmcadams, any updates on this one?
@tysonnorris, can you rebase. What's the status of this one?
@tysonnorris, looks like this one needs a rebase.

@tz70s I opened https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/3479 which should make wskadmin work with python3 (I used 2to3 to scan for areas of concern and addressed the ones necessary). 

Once that PR is accepted/merged, I think you can just update your PR to remove the `find python` method and static field.
cc @dgrove-oss
@rabbah , this helps me a lot, thanks!
Maybe similar approach should be taken: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/3432#issuecomment-373029498
PR failing currently due to #3482 (started post merge of #3077)

@rabbah , I found that there's plenty of places that should not be compatible.
If we really desire to have compatibility, as you mentioned, I think I can work on 2to3 scan associated with a travis build for checking all python 2, 3 code got passed. Should we have an additional branch on here for a visible testing result?
+1 python 3 is a decade old (@cclauss this will make you happy :)
Additional opinion, I think we can block this pr, once all processes finish.

these scripts use the `python` path from `WhiskProperties`

- [x] `wskadmin`
- [ ] `replicateDbs`
- [ ] `cleanUpActivations`
- [ ] `deleteLogsFromActivations`

i checked off `wskadmin` now as python 3 compatible.
@dubee the config changes themselves are fine, in context. I'll comment on the issue with questions/concerns.

I've checked for `cleanUpActivations` and `deleteLogsFromActivations` in pending #3483 . I can't successfully tested with `replicateDbs` seems caused by some additional problems in my settings/mac. (It didn't throw any python error, though) Waiting for travis check.

Maybe some additional utilities? i.e. `scanCode` (I'm sure it's not currently compatible)

I agree, in principle, that the tuning is a good thing. But I'm not so sure about the proposed defaults/baseline. The test machine for which these parameters were determined is described as "44-way with 48GB memory". These numbers definitely look good for that setup, but will they meet the needs of all users? 

Is there an assumption, with OpenWhisk, of what a "default" user machine should look like? There should likely, with the PR, be some documentation addition on user tuning as well.

Removing the WIP tag, because I’ve resolved the namespace oversights as I’ve moved through the runtimes.  It’s necessary to go through the tests in individual runtimes and make sure all are namespaced to `package runtimes.actionContainers`.  There were a couple oversights in the `master` build chain for runtimes (e.g. Java) that should start breaking in Travis builds once this change is committed.  I’ll try to file PRs for pre-emotive strikes on those.

A transition period will be needed to remove deploy builds from the Travis files, after which the shared classes can be factored back into `incubator-openwhisk`.  Or maybe we’ll do that first.  Too many repos and moving parts — time to put some stakes in the ground.

I like that approach, _assuming_ we need to continue to pre-pull Docker images in ansible.  My preferred approach would be for Invoker to pre-pull its needed images on startup.  I’m opening the covers on invoker in my next PR, so can we table this conversation until then?  I’m referring #3407 here so we track this conversation.  I’ll also add a TODO to the Ansible files where the suspect variables are defined and used so we don’t build in more dependencies.  We can disappear them over the next few weeks while the JARs are open.  This PRs intention was to do pre-JAR work.  Deal?
@cclauss first i'd like to get the code compatible, then we can update the docs to make python 3 the default.

As long as we leave the redundant defaults in application.conf so that kube deploy won't suddenly break, I'm ok with staging things and having duplication for a couple of weeks while the changes flow through.

fwiw, in the kube deployments, the pulls are done by an init container that runs before the main invoker container starts.  it does the pulls by reading (a duplicated... 😬 ) runtimes.json file.
@rabbah I was not talking about which is default.  I was talking about how we discover the paths to the executables.
Ah - thanks for clarifying. I'm thinking we can just nuke that method entirely.

> Too many repos

_blame_ @csantanapr  😅
@jonpspri can you clarify: where will the canonical common code be located after this patch?
@starpit ^^
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5099100/37808458-dd16d472-2e20-11e8-9041-6305f0d2bfe0.png)
@rabbah I already addressed all your comments from above. Please take a look at the other changes.
Superseded by #3485. Closing this PR.
PG 2 / 2957 completed successfully.
@cbickel can you please also take a look?

Do we still keep the API swagger current with changes like these? For the OW JS SDK, that file was super useful when implemeting the library. I'm not sure where else we are documenting the API if not there?
My oversight. We should update the swagger.
PG1 2739 is green, @cbickel do you mind merging it?
So basically by moving the properties into reference.conf we assure that any application.conf will override it. Does pureconfig also work with reference.conf? if yes, I'm fine with the change.

PG 2 / 2958 🔵.

PG 3 / 2047 completed unstable with a single failed test, i.e. the expected test failed because there were intentional setting mismatches:

```
Starting test Action limits should reject creation of an action with these limits: timeout: 301 seconds (> max), memory: None, logsize: None at 2018-03-23 09:36:32.093
Exception occurred during test execution: org.scalatest.exceptions.TestFailedException: Unexpected result when creating action 'ActionLimitTests-1521812192093':
exit code = 0
stdout: {"name":"ActionLimitTests-1521812192093","publish":false,"annotations":[{"key":"exec","value":"nodejs:6"}],"version":"0.0.1","exec":{"kind":"nodejs:6","code":"/**\n * Hello, world.\n */\nfunction main(params) {\n    greeting = 'hello, ' + params.payload + '!'\n    console.log(greeting);\n    return {payload: greeting}\n}\n","binary":false},"parameters":[],"limits":{"timeout":301000,"memory":256,"logs":10},"namespace":"lime@us.ibm.com"}
stderr: 
statusCode: 200 OK
respData: {"name":"ActionLimitTests-1521812192093","publish":false,"annotations":[{"key":"exec","value":"nodejs:6"}],"version":"0.0.1","exec":{"kind":"nodejs:6","code":"/**\n * Hello, world.\n */\nfunction main(params) {\n    greeting = 'hello, ' + params.payload + '!'\n    console.log(greeting);\n    return {payload: greeting}\n}\n","binary":false},"parameters":[],"limits":{"timeout":301000,"memory":256,"logs":10},"namespace":"lime@us.ibm.com"}
blocking: false
Failed assertion: 0 was not equal to 144

```

@vvraskin - is it possible that a customer might also experience similar issues due the controller cache invalidation delays?  if so, i think we might need to better understand this distributed cache behavior.. document for support purposes or maybe even to customers.. ?

@mdeuser https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/3032 the fact there are multiple controllers shouldn’t really leak out and the backend should alleviate the races. Namespace stickiness to serialize all crud operations is one approach.

@vvraskin - it sounds like the fix for #3032 is the appropriate remedy for the mainWhisk/8244 test failure reported by this issue.  imho, masking the root cause in each test may not be the way to go as these will serve to validate the eventual #3032 fix.

Agree that this failure should go away with the session stickiness or alike. Given the change is there, I would expect a test that covers this behaviour. 
With the system as it is now, the assumption '404 must be returned right after the trigger deletion' is not valid and I think that the fix corrects it. Otherwise the test is occasionally false positive.
Other solution suggested in https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/1815#issuecomment-277844752
@vvraskin - i understand your point, but if i understand correctly, the reason the test failed was due to cross-controller cache consistency and not due to an incorrect test implementation.. ?
